artworks.title: Untitled (Skull)
artworks.description: A haunting vision suspended between life and death, where listless eyes meet explosive internal energy in a mask of both vulnerability and power.

artworks.title: Untitled
artworks.description: A fiery devil erupts across sixteen feet of canvas, rendered in sporadic brushwork and vivid colors that pulse with raw, primal energy.

artworks.title: Dustheads
artworks.description: Two frenetic, radiant souls blaze against darkness, capturing the desperate euphoria of addiction with urgent, electric intensity.

artworks.title: La Hara
artworks.description: A menacing white skeletal officer looms in midnight blue against burning red, his cage-like hat imprisoning perception itself.

artworks.title: Untitled (Warrior)
artworks.description: A regal warrior rises from street walls to gallery heights, crowned in poetry and graffiti, marking transcendence through sheer creative force.

artworks.title: The Field Next to the Other Road
artworks.description: A skeletal man walks his cow through fields of color, a pastoral moment rendered in the language of streets transformed into art.

artworks.title: Untitled (Fisherman)
artworks.description: Crowned with thorns and haloed in light, a black fisherman stands proud, his catch suspended between earthly triumph and spiritual transcendence.

artworks.title: Irony of a Negro Policeman
artworks.description: A caged consciousness in midnight blue, where the oppressed wears the oppressor's uniform, revealing hypocrisy through whitewashed features and Baron Samedi's shadow.

artworks.title: Cadillac Moon
artworks.description: Television faces stack toward the moon while Cadillacs cruise through frenetic prayers of paint, capturing the electric chaos of downtown dreams.

artworks.title: Bird on Money
artworks.description: A blue yardbird soars through symbols and arrows toward Green-Wood Cemetery, where jazz legend and future artist meet in transcendent improvisation.

artworks.title: Warrior
artworks.description: A commanding gladiator brandishes his sword against yellow and blue, channeling Renaissance knights through the raw energy of basement studios.

artworks.title: Crown Hotel (Mona Lisa Black Background)
artworks.description: Complexity and depth converge in a powerful reimagining where crowns meet classical mystery against darkness, bridging centuries of artistic dialogue.

artworks.title: Equals Pi
artworks.description: Robin egg blue holds the crown, a skeletal king, and mathematical truths, where dunce caps meet equations in Tiffany's signature hue.

artworks.title: Charles the First
artworks.description: A crown floats above Thor's name as young kings face decapitation, merging bebop jazz, graffiti royalty, and cartoon legacy into one prophetic masterpiece.

artworks.title: Leonardo da Vinci's Greatest Hits
artworks.description: Renaissance anatomy meets folk hero John Henry beneath triple crowns, creating an encyclopedia of artistic obsession across collaged white space.

artworks.title: The Guilt of Gold Teeth
artworks.description: Baron Samedi stretches nearly fourteen feet across canvas, the keeper of death watching over gold teeth's burden in top hat and painted skull.

artworks.title: Versus Medici
artworks.description: At twenty-one, a young king boldly crowns himself successor to Renaissance masters, channeling Savonarola's revolutionary spirit against the establishment.

artworks.title: Untitled (One Eyed Man or Xerox Face)
artworks.description: A one-eyed face emerges from Xerox machine dreams, capturing the mechanical reproduction of identity in a watershed year of artistic explosion.

artworks.title: Untitled (Head)
artworks.description: Supernatural hues explode from an African mask-like visage, creating urgency and immediacy that captures 1980s New York's psychological pulse.

artworks.title: Red Skull
artworks.description: A potent skull blazes red with Vodou symbolism and Gray's Anatomy echoes, bridging childhood hospital memories and Haitian heritage in searing color.

artworks.title: Boy and Dog in a Johnnypump
artworks.description: Skeletal boy and dog dance in fire hydrant spray beneath blazing summer colors, capturing the joy of New York childhood in monumental scale.

artworks.title: Dustheads
artworks.description: Two frenetic, radiant souls blaze against darkness, capturing the desperate euphoria of addiction with urgent, electric intensity.

artworks.title: Untitled (Pollo Frito)
artworks.description: The radiant child escapes Brooklyn's determinism through paint, though disillusionment and addiction shadow this breakthrough portrait of defiant becoming.

artworks.title: Untitled (Gem Spa)
artworks.description: Surrounded by asphalt, tar, and partially obscured words, a radiant child emerges from SAMO's death to claim artistic immortality at a turning point.

artworks.title: A Panel of Experts
artworks.description: Love and jealousy converge in paint and fire, marking the turbulent intersection of romance, ambition, and creative rage in downtown Manhattan.

artworks.title: Dos Cabezas
artworks.description: Two heads, two legends, one Polaroid moment—the only joint portrait of an iconic friendship that would reshape 1980s art forever.

artworks.title: Hannibal
artworks.description: Built from found materials and rope, a warrior emerges on roughly hewn canvas, surviving smuggling and scandal to command thirteen million.

artworks.title: Donut Revenge
artworks.description: A crowned, goggle-eyed character floats with bulbous humor, his chest proclaiming 'Little Fat Man with a Chicken Leg' in vibrant, playful defiance.

artworks.title: Flesh and Spirit
artworks.description: Twelve feet square of hinged panels where skeleton, brain, and disembodied hand explore the threshold between physical flesh and transcendent spirit.

artworks.title: In This Case
artworks.description: The final skull in a sacred trilogy blazes with green teeth and yellow eye—not memento mori, but amplified memory played devastatingly loud.

artworks.title: Hollywood Africans
artworks.description: Three friends counter Hollywood stereotypes in a Los Angeles photo booth, reclaiming identity through paint while studying movie stars' footprints.

artworks.title: Defacement (The Death of Michael Stewart)
artworks.description: Rage and grief converge on Haring's studio wall after police violence kills a graffiti artist—'it could have been me'—painted in devastating immediacy.

artworks.title: History of the Black People
artworks.description: Three hinged panels reclaim Egyptian blackness, crossing out the Nile's letters as Osiris guides boats past the grand spectacle of slavery's centuries.

artworks.title: Sabado por la Noche
artworks.description: Saturday night comes alive through two griots—West African storytellers meeting Nuyorican streets in a symphony of cultural memory and modern chaos.

artworks.title: Flexible
artworks.description: A griot rises eight feet tall on deconstructed fence slats, arms joined above his head in a continuous band of West African storytelling power.

artworks.title: Jim Crow
artworks.description: Red eyes glow from a featureless face dissolving into skeletal ribs, painted across whitewashed slats with Mississippi's name in gold and green.

artworks.title: Olympics
artworks.description: Pop art elder meets neo-expressionist prodigy in collaborative fusion, where silkscreen meets spontaneous paint in the resurgence of two legends.

artworks.title: Taxi 45th/Broadway
artworks.description: A black man labeled 'NEGRO' waves desperately at 45th and Broadway while a white driver curses past—racism rendered in collaborative paint.

artworks.title: Zenith
artworks.description: Commercial image meets expressive rebellion as Warhol's Zenith logo erupts with Basquiat's marks in the apex of their 'crazy art-world marriage.'

artworks.title: World Crown
artworks.description: Skeleton faces black figure in a boxing match beneath floating crowns, where mortality meets resilience in the artist's quest for recognition.

artworks.title: Pork
artworks.description: Chaotic brushstrokes and skeletal figures collide with the scrawled word 'PORK,' creating raw urgency that critiques authority through layered, visceral intensity.

artworks.title: Untitled (Julius Caesar on Gold)
artworks.description: A fragmented Caesar rises from gleaming gold, where power and mortality dance in jagged lines across a backdrop of wealth and historical weight.

artworks.title: Portrait of A-One A.K.A. King
artworks.description: A vibrant homage to graffiti brotherhood erupts in skeletal mask and energetic color, capturing A-One's street king intensity and urban heroism.

artworks.title: Rape of the Roman Torsos
artworks.description: Fragmented, violently distorted torsos writhe in red and black, where classical antiquity meets raw modernity in a provocative clash of eras.

artworks.title: Obnoxious Liberals
artworks.description: Mask-like heads clash in bold confrontation, where the provocative title meets vibrant chaos to challenge hierarchies and expose cultural hypocrisy.

artworks.title: Offensive Orange
artworks.description: Bold orange blazes with confrontational energy as skeletal forms and scattered symbols merge spontaneity with provocative, visceral intensity.

artworks.title: Slave Auction
artworks.description: Jagged faces and fragmented forms convey anguish in bold reds and blacks, confronting viewers with the brutal weight of historical trauma.

artworks.title: Native Carrying Some Guns, Bibles, Amorites Safari
artworks.description: Colonial history erupts in satirical narrative where guns meet Bibles across skeletal forms, critiquing exploitation through chaotic, symbolic intensity.

artworks.title: Both Poles
artworks.description: Opposing forces collide in skeletal figures and cryptic marks, where dualities and tensions create visual electricity across fragmented composition.

artworks.title: Mona Lisa
artworks.description: The Renaissance icon explodes into skeletal graffiti, where classical refinement meets raw street energy in an irreverent, brilliant collision of art history.
